note: Gibbon. Crook left his base camp on Goose Creek on August 5; his column now numbered 2,000 men. Terry left his new supply depot at the mouth of the Rosebud River on August 8; his column now numbered 1,700 men. They met upstream on the Rosebud on August 10 and combined forces. See Utley, Frontier Regulars, 268–69.

title: The Lakota agencies were Red Cloud, for the Oglalas (established in its thencurrent location in 1871
The Killing of Crazy Horse

note: Friswald, The Killing of Crazy Horse; Kadlecek and Kadlecek, To Kill an Eagle: Indian Views on the Last Days of Crazy Horse; and Hardorff, The Surrender and Death of Crazy Horse.
title: In the transcript, Black Elk says little about the death of Crazy Horse (see Sixth Grandfather, 203–4). Most of the material in this chapter was provided by Neihardt. Crazy Horse was killed at Fort Robinson on September 5, 1877, while resisting arrest. See Olson, Red Cloud and the Sioux Problem, 237–49; Sandoz, Crazy Horse: The Strange Man of the Oglalas, 360–413; Bray, Crazy Horse: A Lakota Life, 374–90. Among the many sources on Crazy Horse’s death, see Brininstool, Crazy Horse: The Invincible Ogalala Sioux Chief

note: See Hyde, Red Cloud’s Folk, 284–85; Olson, Red Cloud and the Sioux Problem, 231–33.
title: In August 1876 the army took over temporary control of the Sioux agencies. Soon after the chiefs signed the Black Hills cession agreement, the army confiscated the Lakotas’ guns and horses and forced them to move their camps to the agencies where they could be closely watched

note: See Hyde, Red Cloud’s Folk, 285–86; Olson, Red Cloud and the Sioux Problem, 233–34. Notes to
title: After confiscating the horses belonging to the Oglalas, Gen. Crook called the men to a meeting at Fort Robinson for the purpose of announcing that he had deposed Red Cloud as head chief and now recognized Spotted Tail as chief of all the Lakotas at both Red Cloud and Spotted Tail Agencies

note: After spending some time on Powder River they continued north and joined Sitting Bull in Canada. See Hyde, Red Cloud’s Folk, 299–300; Olson, Red Cloud and the Sioux Problem, 247–56; McCrady, Living with Strangers, 73–75.
title: The first two paragraphs of this chapter present material that is not found in the transcript. In 1877 Congress insisted that the Oglalas and Brules be moved to the Missouri River; if they refused, they would receive no rations. A delegation of chiefs visited Washington in September 1877 and received President Hayes’s promise that if they agreed to spend the winter on the Missouri, in the spring they could choose new agency sites within the Great Sioux Reservation. Although Crazy Horse’s old band, now led by Big Road, started to make the move, they eventually broke away and headed north
White Mud or Frenchman River

note: See McCrady, Living with Strangers, 76–102. Vestal, Sitting Bull: Champion of the Sioux, 210, reports that Sitting Bull also held a Sun Dance there the previous summer, 1877.

title: The Buffalo Bill show, including 133 Indians (Lakotas, Cheyennes, Arapahos, Kiowas, and Pawnees), left New York on the steamship State of Nebraska on March 31, 1887, bound for England (“Buffalo Bill’s Good-Bye

note: Buffalo Bill’s Wild West opened officially on May 9 and closed on October 31 (Russell, The Lives and Legends of Buffalo Bill, 327–29; Yost, Buffalo Bill, 186–203; Sell and Weybright, Buffalo Bill and the Wild West, 159–76; Gallop, Buffalo Bill’s British Wild West, 54–129). 324 Notes to
title: Buffalo Bill’s troop arrived at Gravesend on April 16, 1887; the next day they sailed up the Thames to London and then took a train to Earl’s Court, where the show’s headquarters and exhibition arena were still under construction. The show was part of the American Exposition that was organized as part of the celebration of the Golden Jubilee of Queen Victoria’s reign

publisher: Gallop, Buffalo Bill’s British Wild West
title: The private command performance for Queen Victoria at Earl’s Court was held on May 11, 1887. See Russell, The Lives and Legends of Buffalo Bill, 330; Sell and Weybright, Buffalo Bill and the Wild West, 169–71

note: Sixth Grandfather, 249); Neihardt corrected it.
title: In the transcript, Black Elk gives the Queen’s age as seventy-five

note: where it ran from November 6 to November 26, then on to Manchester, where it opened on December 17 and closed on April 30, 1888. See Russell, The Lives and Legends of Buffalo Bill, 204–8; Gallop, Buffalo Bill’s British Wild West, 133–50.
title: Buffalo Bill’s performers were assigned seats in one of the grandstands constructed for the spectacular parade of European royalty celebrating Queen Victoria’s Golden Jubilee. See Gallop, Buffalo Bill’s British Wild West, 112. The Spirit Journey 1. After closing in London, the show moved first to Birmingham

publisher: Gallop, Buffalo Bill’s British Wild West
title: Following a final performance in Hull on May 5, Buffalo Bill sailed for New York on May 6, 1888. See Russell, The Lives and Legends of Buffalo Bill, 204–8

note: He apparently sailed from Baltimore in July 1887. See Sixth Grandfather, 252n10.
title: Captain Mexican Joe Shelly organized a rival Wild West Show to compete with Buffalo Bill
Mexican Joe’s show apparently visited Naples, where Black Elk learned about Pompeii

note: Yost, Buffalo Bill, 221; Russell, The Lives and Legends of Buffalo Bill, 350).
title: Buffalo Bill’s Wild West opened in Paris at the Exposition Universelle on May 10, 1889

note: See Olson, Red Cloud and the Sioux Problem, 312–19; Hyde, A Sioux Chronicle, 198–228. The Messiah
title: This was in the year of the treaty (1889

The 1889 agreement reduced the Great Sioux Reservation by about half (eleven million acres) and created five smaller reservations out of the remainder. To the north, above the Cheyenne River, were Standing Rock and Cheyenne River Reservations; to the south, below the White River, were Pine Ridge, Rosebud, and Lower Brule Reservations

note: See Ostler, The Plains Sioux and U.S. Colonialism, 237–38; Olson, Red Cloud and the Sioux Problem, 320; Hyde, A Sioux Chronicle, 230–31.
title: The three introductory paragraphs are Neihardt’s. After the Sioux signed the 1889 agreement, the commissioner of Indian affairs reduced their beef rations by half

note: See Olson, Red Cloud and the Sioux Problem, 320–21; Mooney, The Ghost-Dance Religion, 826–42. Notes to
